When an application-remove is requested: 
* check the states of the helm releases (or fluxcd HelmRelease) for that app and any release that is in a bad state either rollback or delete via the helm command (or kubectl delete <helmrelease>).

base-files-config/source/vimrc.local.message:
Hi, I think this should be

  set mouse=

to disable the use of mouse for all modes. I have verified that this commands disables mouse for good on an internal build server. (I first used ":set mouse=a", observed that mouse was being used, and then I used ":set mouse=", and I observed that the mouse is no longer being used.)

Here is the help text, quoted from vim's documentation:

```
'mouse'                 string  (default "", "a" for GUI, MS-DOS and Win32)
                        global
                        {not in Vi}
        Enable the use of the mouse.  Only works for certain terminals
        (xterm, MS-DOS, Win32 win32-mouse, QNX pterm, *BSD console with
        sysmouse and Linux console with gpm).  For using the mouse in the
        GUI, see gui-mouse.
        The mouse can be enabled for different modes:
                n       Normal mode
                v       Visual mode
                i       Insert mode
                c       Command-line mode
                h       all previous modes when editing a help file
                a       all previous modes
                r       for hit-enter and more-prompt prompt
        Normally you would enable the mouse in all four modes with:
                :set mouse=a
        When the mouse is not enabled, the GUI will still use the mouse for
        modeless selection.  This doesn't move the text cursor.
```

Hi, I do not know the default value of mouse in Debian-based StarlingX, however, using "set mouse=" to unset all mouse options should do it, I think.

Example:

```
set mouse=v
set mouse-=a
set mouse?
```

The last command prints out:

```
mouse=v
```

My point with this example is that for the "-=" operation to work, the exact option must already be in the value. If "a" is not in the "mouse" option's value, then using "set mouse-=a" will not do anything.

In summary, we should use "set mouse=" to unset all mouse options.

I also think that Chuck should verify these a bit further. This commit is not yet ready for review, in my opinion.

This will *disable* paste mode, meaning that the indentation will stay active. 

Enabling the paste mode with "set paste" would probably be a sledgehammer approach.

As I explained in the internal ticket, we should instead disable the indentation behaviour, possibly by disabling the filetype plugin and/or unsetting the autoindent, smartindent, cindent, indentexpr, indentkeys options. This requires some experimentation and testing.
I disagree with setting paste. As mentioned before, it really is a sledgehammer. However, if that is what you prefer, I will not prevent this from going in.
Fixed, I am leaving as is.

cve_support/cve_policy_filter.py.message:
This condition normally tells you that a CVE was not fixed despite the presence of a fix released LP.  We normally trust Vuls scanner to tell us when a package is vulnerable.  We want to continue to have visibility for this condition.

The reason you want to create this exclusion is because you are aware that Vuls has misrepresented the fix status of an 'stx' versioned package.  We recognize that Vuls cannot know the status of 'stx' versioned packages.

You want to omit it from report, that is ok.  Please do not just ignore the condition, but convert it to a warning.  Add a log message that the analyst running this script can review.

We want to recognize when a fixed LP is actually not fixed.  There are several reasons why this may be, such as: a newer fixed is provided under the same CVE; an engineer has failed to apply the correct package version.

> The examples there do not cover some cases.

Right, could you discuss those cases here, in the spec? (not in the comments)

> I went directly to the code

Hmm well I don't really agree that the code being unclear is a reason to change the functionality, it's a good argument for improving the documentation though.

Can you explain (in the spec, not in a comment) the answer to my second question, why are local users not sufficient?

The examples there do not cover some cases. Therefore, when I started working with identity federation in Keystone, I went directly to the code, and I checked the schema to understand what I could define as the mapping. Then, I saw that at the root of the `local` rules, we had a domain definition (https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/b0b93c03986f3bb40c5a2ec31ee37c83014e197a/keystone/federation/utils.py#L118). I also saw domain options for the `user` and `group` options. Therefore, I thought that those could be used as an override, and this one (https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/b0b93c03986f3bb40c5a2ec31ee37c83014e197a/keystone/federation/utils.py#L118) was somehow the default for the mapping rule. I only discovered that this was not the case when I started testing, and then I checked how the mapping was being processed.

Is this meant to map users to existing local projects, or to auto-provision new projects in the given domain? If the latter, what is to prevent collisions between mapped projects and potential existing local projects?
Done
Both. If the project does not exist, we create it. If it exist we use it. That is already what happens if you define a mapping to an existing project.

Since this is already the case for auto-provisioned projects, this would seem to be a backwards compatible change since operators need to provide the domain in order to opt into this behavior, so I wonder why the schema version would be needed?

Yes, we also discussed that already here. However, for now, this need did not show up in PROD. However, to implement it, we would like a mechanism to enable/disable these features. That is why this versioning is important.

To honor the domain that is defined in the root of the `local` rules, and to use the other domain definition as overrides. 

This proposal here is just providing a simple use case for the use of the attribute mapping schema version.

I am not understanding what you mean. The default domain definition in the "local" property of the attribute mapping rule was not being used. Therefore, what we are proposing and doing here is to consider it. Therefore, one can, for instance, define a user or a project, without a domain, and then we check if there is a domain in the local section of the mapping rule, if there is, we use it; otherwise, we take the domain of the IdP.

Why is this called "Minimal Version"? Seems we rather list current versions at the time of the last update of this document?

Is this expected to be kept uptodate for stable branches?
Maybe some more explanatory text about the purpose and design of this table might then be needed in the description above. In the current form to me this is more confusing than helpful.

One of things we do during cycle is deciding which versions we use. MariaDB 10.6.*, Erlang 25.* etc.

There were moments when those version were going out of sync between distros/archs and people were asking which version should be used. So I created this doc to show which versions are used around end of cycle.

It is not updated during stable unless for some reason we would need to bump it (which reminds me that I should check erlang/rabbitmq in older branches).
Wouldn't this also need to be replaced by opensearch now?
The minimum(2.15,2.17)=2.15, why do we need to list two versions here?

We have long history of fighting with openvswitch 2.15/2.17 so I prefer to have clean info which version is where.

2.17 is kind of "we prefer" while 2.15 is "good enough"

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think this is because the new ISO isn't labeled correctly. The installer will  eject based on:

 # Eject installer ISO image if available
 isodev=$(blkid --label ${ISO_INSTLABEL} -o device)
 if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
	eject $isodev
 fi

where iso label is derived from an installer parameter

  instiso=ISO_LABEL		- The label of installer ISO image

That gets baked into the ISO build, so when crack open an ISO and modify it, I do the follwoing

    ISO_LABEL=$(grep -ri instiso isolinux/isolinux.cfg | head -1 | xargs -n1 | awk -F= /instiso/'{print $2}')
    mkisofs -R -D -A ${ISO_LABEL} -V ${ISO_LABEL} \
     <snip>
    -o ${OUT_ISO_PATH} \
    ${TMP_PATCH_ISO_DIR}

That seems to allow the existing eject mechanism to work.

Would it be possible to check whether the attributes are already set correctly or not, before resetting them? Maybe something like the following? (If you decide to use this, please test it though, ideally *without* the other commit in this topic.)

```
ACTION=="add|change", SUBSYSTEM=="block", KERNEL=="sd[a-z]", \
  PROGRAM="/usr/local/bin/is-rootdisk-device.sh %E{DEVNAME}", RESULT=="?*", \

# === === === ===
# Check the I/O scheduler settings. If they are already correct, then

ACTION=="add|change", ENV{nodetype}=="controller", SUBSYSTEM=="block", \

  ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="bfq", \

  ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="mq-deadline", \
  ATTR{queue/iosched/front_merges}=="0", \
  ATTR{queue/iosched/read_expire}=="150", \
  ATTR{queue/iosched/write_expire}=="1500", \
  GOTO="io_scheduler_end"

# HP ProLiant DL360p Gen8; HP ProLiant DL380p Gen8
ACTION=="add|change", SUBSYSTEM=="block", KERNEL=="sd[a-z]", \
  ATTRS{raid_level}=="*RAID*", \
  ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="none", \
  GOTO="io_scheduler_end"
   
# Dell Inc. PowerEdge R720
ACTION=="add|change", SUBSYSTEM=="block", KERNEL=="sd[a-z]", \
  ATTRS{label}=="*RAID*", \
  ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="none", \
  GOTO="io_scheduler_end"

# === === === ===
# If we are here, then the I/O scheduler settings are not as expected

ACTION=="add|change", ENV{nodetype}=="controller", SUBSYSTEM=="block", \
  KERNEL=="sd[a-z]", ENV{rootdisk}=="1", \
  ATTR{queue/scheduler}="bfq", \
  ATTR{queue/iosched/strict_guarantees}="1"

ACTION=="add|change", SUBSYSTEM=="block", KERNEL=="sd[a-z]", ENV{rootdisk}!="1", \
  ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="mq-deadline", \
  ATTR{queue/iosched/front_merges}="0", \
  ATTR{queue/iosched/read_expire}="150", \
  ATTR{queue/iosched/write_expire}="1500"

# Set none io scheduler for variants of HW-RAID.
# HP ProLiant DL360p Gen8; HP ProLiant DL380p Gen8
ACTION=="add|change", SUBSYSTEM=="block", KERNEL=="sd[a-z]", \
  ATTRS{raid_level}=="*RAID*", \
  ATTR{queue/scheduler}="none"
   
# Dell Inc. PowerEdge R720
ACTION=="add|change", SUBSYSTEM=="block", KERNEL=="sd[a-z]", \
  ATTRS{label}=="*RAID*",\
  ATTR{queue/scheduler}="none"

# === === === ===
LABEL="io_scheduler_end"
```

Ok, I spent a lot more time on this than I thought I would, but I got it to work...

The problem is that the queue/scheduler file prints out text like the following, which confuses the udev matcher with =="bfq" or =="mq-deadline":

```
sysadmin@controller-0:~$ cat /sys/block/sda/queue/scheduler
mq-deadline kyber [bfq] none
```

The solution is below. Feel free to remove the logger lines. They were intended for debugging...

```
# Need nodetype environment variable
IMPORT{file}="/etc/platform/platform.conf"

ACTION!="add|change", GOTO="iosched_end"
SUBSYSTEM!="block", GOTO="iosched_end"
KERNEL!="sd[a-z]", GOTO="iosched_end"

PROGRAM="/usr/local/bin/is-rootdisk-device.sh %E{DEVNAME}", RESULT=="?*", ENV{rootdisk}="1"

### Test
ATTRS{raid_level}=="*RAID*", \
    ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="none", \
    RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -s -p daemon.err -t stx-iosched 'skip RAID1 %k %N'", \
    GOTO="iosched_end"

ATTRS{label}=="*RAID*", \
    ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="none", \
    RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -s -p daemon.err -t stx-iosched 'skip RAID2 %k %N'", \
    GOTO="iosched_end"

ENV{nodetype}=="controller", \
    ENV{rootdisk}=="1", \
    ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="*\[bfq\]*", \
    ATTR{queue/iosched/strict_guarantees}=="1", \
    RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -s -p daemon.err -t stx-iosched 'skip bfq %k %N'", \
    GOTO="iosched_end"

ENV{rootdisk}!="1", \
    ATTR{queue/scheduler}=="*\[mq-deadline\]*", \
    ATTR{queue/iosched/front_merges}=="0", \
    ATTR{queue/iosched/read_expire}=="150", \
    ATTR{queue/iosched/write_expire}=="1500", \
    RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -s -p daemon.err -t stx-iosched 'skip mq-deadline %k %N'", \
    GOTO="iosched_end"

### Set
ATTRS{raid_level}=="*RAID*", \
    ATTR{queue/scheduler}="none", \
    RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -s -p daemon.err -t stx-iosched 'set RAID1 %k %N'", \
    GOTO="iosched_end"

ATTRS{label}=="*RAID*", \
    ATTR{queue/scheduler}="none", \
    RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -s -p daemon.err -t stx-iosched 'set RAID2 %k %N'", \
    GOTO="iosched_end"

ENV{nodetype}=="controller", \
    ENV{rootdisk}=="1", \
    ATTR{queue/scheduler}="bfq", \
    ATTR{queue/iosched/strict_guarantees}="1", \
    RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -s -p daemon.err -t stx-iosched 'set bfq %k %N'", \
    GOTO="iosched_end"

ENV{rootdisk}!="1", \
    ATTR{queue/scheduler}="mq-deadline", \
    ATTR{queue/iosched/front_merges}="0", \
    ATTR{queue/iosched/read_expire}="150", \
    ATTR{queue/iosched/write_expire}="1500", \
    RUN+="/usr/bin/logger -s -p daemon.err -t stx-iosched 'set mq-deadline %k %N'", \
    GOTO="iosched_end"

LABEL="iosched_end"
```

Hi, sorry for my very late reply.

I am wondering what the behaviour should be for the following case:

  The system is not a controller, but the disk is a root disk.

In such a case, should the I/O scheduler left at its default, or should it be set to "mq-deadline"? If mq-deadline is desired, then perhaps the ENV{rootdisk}!="1" could be removed from this stanza and the corresponding stanza in the next section? (If we do not do that, I am assuming that the default I/O scheduler would be used.)

Please note that I am not familiar with the selection criteria, so we may need help from someone who knows the history behind these selections.

Hi, no problem.

Looking at the base version, this behavior should be set to "mq-deadline". And we really don't need ENV{rootdisk}!="1" in the case, since we are using GOTO. That is, if it is not RAID, not controller and not rootdisk, it should be set to mq-deadline.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I hit this problem setting up a new build environment on a system with a limited sized root filesystem '/'. I was running out of space when building the ceph package. Looked like I needed at least 40G free space (which I didn't) so the build failed.

So now that this is moved to the "pkgbuilder's private directory on the shared volume", where is this location? Do I just need to make sure that my /localdisk has plenty of space?

Thank you to review this. When setting up the new build environment, there is 'STX_BUILD_HOME' to define the location of shared volume on host, the default location for this on host is '/localdisk/$USER', and the developer should make sure that there is enough disk size for it. Then all the containers(builder, pkgbuilder, repomgr and lat) should consume the disk of 'STX_BUILD_HOME', but we found that the pkgbuilder container sets its '/build' director under '/' internally, actually '/' is '/overlay' on host, this causes the issue "E: Disk space is probably not sufficient for building" during our tests, so this commit changes the '/build' directory of schroot in pkgbuilder to ${STX_BUILD_HOME}/localdisk/pkgbuilder/${USER}/${PROJECT}/chroots/<schroot_name_[digit]>/build, in other word, it has been switched from host overlay to the shared volume.

stx/toCOPY/pkgbuilder/setup.sh.message:
the sbuild owners thought maping /build to an alternate location was a good idea.   Do we really want to delete the mapping entirely?  

Did you consider mapping it through to some place under /localdisk ?
Yes, it has been mapped to the shared volume: ${STX_BUILD_HOME}/localdisk/pkgbuilder/${USER}/${PROJECT}/chroots/<schroot_name_[digit]>/build".

trove/instance/models.py.message:
The change should fix the issue.

I'm wondering, however, how allowing empty value for "device_path" impacts other places in the code. In my opinion, putting "device_path =" without value into configuration is invalid and should be reported to the user - by putting a key user expressed an intent, but empty value is invalid as device path.

We should consider enforcing value by adding "required" flag to some options in the configuration or enhance definitions by regex.

By design, we have:
* while volume_support is disabled
  * if device_path is set, nova local disks are used;
  * otherwise, nova ephmeral disks are used.

However:
* checking device_path is not consistent in different code path;
* the actual device path is in fact controller by the underly hypervisor and the guest OS.

It may not easy to get a correct regex matching the actual device path, so for now the solution may be add some helper methods or logic to determine whether local or ephemeral disks are used, and use them consistently.
Of course, this is an idea that should be developed in a separate change.

openstack/cloud/openstackcloud.py.message:
Are these expected to be passed as positional arguments? If not, how about marking them as kwarg-only?

  def search_resources(
      self,
      service_proxy,
      resource_type,
      name_or_id,
      *,
      get_args=None,
      ...
  ):

actually here I want to build possibility to override args and kwargs of get and find calls individually (i.e. in get user might want to use different base_url, but not in list). And kwargs themselves are what is considered as filter.

Okay. You could still use a kwarg-only argument though. This way it'd be more explicit what you're doing. For example:

  search_resources(
      conn,
      'compute.Flavor',
      'm1.',
      list_args={'detailed': True},
  )

But it's up to you, really.
Why do we need to cast this instead of returning a generator? Couldn't the caller do this cast if they needed to?
sadly now cloud layer is not returning generators and everywhere we explicitly cast. Just wanted at least on that keep compatibility
This seems a bit weird. Why can't we pass the actual object? Better yet, why can't we implement a 'search_foo' method for each resource type like we have 'get_foo' and 'find_foo' methods?
Not done but moved so new comment

atm we do not have search_XXX for all of the supported resources. And where we have them they are also not consistent. Ansible has a very specific usecase of having name_or_id and additional filters and expect one or multiple resources. This can be only achieved like implemented here by invoking get and list. But doing same work in every ansible module is also not a very useful way, so I came with this function. It can be placed to ansible base class itself, but that would also mean that all search_XXX functions are not used by anybody at all and we should drop them. With this function we could at least have a replacement working consistently for every resource

Point is that once invoked from Ansible (or honestly from anywhere) requiring passing object (or better to say class) requires explicit knowing which class it really is. In most cases this is doable, but once few API versions are available it becomes tricky. Also it requires explicit import from the code (or having "import openstack") - that is for ansible modules too heavy. This is an attempt to make this easy to use

Douple mentionioning of the driver imho. Maybe better
"… checks to the vmdk.py driver at check_for_setup_errors() time to ensure …"

I'd also rewrite this as "… ensure the storage profiles set in the vmware_storage_profile config settings exist in vcenter."

cinder/volume/drivers/vmware/vmdk.py.message:
Using "pbm.get_profile_id_by_name()" here might be inefficient for multiple defined storage profiles, because it will retrieve all profiles and then for-loop over them and filter by name (https://github.com/openstack/oslo.vmware/blob/master/oslo_vmware/pbm.py#L111)
It might be worth extending either oslo.vmware to be able to search for multiple profile names or inlining that for-loop like we do already on line 417 in "_get_datastore_summaries()".

check_for_setup_error is only called once at driver startup.  So yes, we could inline a single call and for loop to do a search more efficiently, but that's really optimizing a call that happens once at startup for a small dataset.  The same call is made several more times throughout the life of the driver during other volume operations.    

So, I think the right thing to do here is to update oslo.vmware to find a different way of fetching the specific profile.  either way, this patch would benefit from that once that is complete.  In the mean time we have fixed a bug in this driver by ensuring that the profile exists at startup.

I agree, that it doesn't matter much for single use. I just don't want anybody to take this as an example when trying to access profiles again.

The other code I found always fetches a single profile - that of the volume - and doesn't iterate over all profiles enabled for the driver. It doesn't look nice that it has to use a for-loop on the vmware side, but it's a single for-loop at least, while accessing all profiles this way is one for-loop per profile.

Still, as said, it's not critical and fixing the bug is worth more.

InstanceQuiesceFailed exception makes sense.

the image is declaring that guest must have its files system frozen and ware are unable to do so because the QEMU guest agent is not in stall.

in the specific case of the bug the image properly was likely set incorrectly on the image since the expectation is that if you set that then teh guest agent will be installed in the image.


its not a 400 as the request is valid but the state of the vm does not full file the preconditions in this case that the guest agent is installed in the image as required by 

$ openstack image create --disk-format raw --container-format bare \
      --property description=test --property hw_disk_bus=scsi \
      --property hw_qemu_guest_agent=yes \
      --property hw_scsi_model=virtio-scsi \
      --property os_require_quiesce=yes --file ubuntu2004.img test-image
      
so I think 409 conflict is correct as its in an invalid state for the operation given the the requirement to quiesce the disk that has explicitly been imposed.

1) I would use something more specific than NovaException here. I would add a new exception like InstanceQuiesceFailed(Invalid) (similarly to the existing InstanceQuiesceNotSupported exception)
2) then most probably in the API layer we don't need to catch anything extra as the Invalid base exception is translated to HTTP 400 response automatically. (need test cases to see if the automatic translation works for each affected action as I'm not 100% sure)
3) to answer you question, as quiesce is used there that code path is affected, but if you follow the above points then you probably don't need to add specific code there.

You should not match strings if possible as these string might change without any notice. If you look at the bugreport then the stack trace there states that:
  nova.exception.InternalError: Error from libvirt while quiescing instance-001f899f: [Error Code 86] Guest agent is not responding: QEMU guest agent is not connected

So we know that libvirt has a specific error code for this issue. 86. This is less likely to change without notice.

There is a constant for it in the libvirt library based on https://libvirt.org/docs/libvirt-appdev-guide-python/en-US/html/libvirt_application_development_guide_using_python-Error_Handling.html

You are raising a new exception type here so you need to make sure that this is properly handle somewhere higher in the call stack. I would add a functional test that injects this error on the libvirt driver level and assert that the API response is not HTTP 500 any more.

Here you have the list of constants that is exposed in the python binding[1]. So you can simply use

    if error_code == libvirt.​VIR_ERR_AGENT_UNRESPONSIVE:
    
instead of the magic number 86.

[1] https://libvirt.org/docs/libvirt-appdev-guide-python/en-US/html/libvirt_application_development_guide_using_python-Error_Handling.html

neutron/db/api.py.message: This will change the semantics of what happens on duplicatekey violations because this branch will result in the entire transaction failing. We depend on being able to catch duplicate key and continuing in cases so this can't be changed like this. I think we will instead need to work to get rid of the existing usage of 'autonested_transaction' if we don't have support for nested transactions.

MySQL Cluster does not support savepoints and rollbacks, so nesting and sub transactions have to be disabled. Where is the code for trying to capture duplicate keys and what is the expected behavior? I'm sure we can figure out another way to implement that functionality without depending on this functionality.
In order to see how this breaks, just disable nesting entirely. We should have consistent behavior WRT transactions independent of the backend.

Yes, we need to disable nesting entirely if the suggestion is that we don't depend on nested transactions. It's feasible that some of the duplicate detection could be easily replaced,  and if that's the case then there is no reason to depend on nested transactions at all.

My team has been testing this for a while without any issues. Is neutron primarily using nesting to catch duplicates and deadlocks? Or is it a performance issue? I know with NDB, it's better to have a bunch of smaller transactions because of the way it scales out. If you think it makes sense to disable nesting altogether, I can work on that next and post an updated revision.
can you explain why this is safe?
NDB doesn't support nested transactions. So, disable nesting only if the engine is ndb

We need to have the same number of chars, that we have set in model. Making size different should be a separate change and I don't think is really needed.

This is to keep the table rows within the 14k limit of NDB. This function will determine if we are using InnoDB or NDB and set the size based on the two parameters passed. I cut the size here because I couldn't find any examples in the code base where this would take up more than 128 chars. If we want to preserve the 255 chars for the string, we can instead convert this to TinyText.

why You allow to change IP address on shared network? It isn't allowed by default on port create so this is kind of inconsistency and with this setting user will be not able to explicitly choose IP address for port created on shared network but will then be able to update his port and choose any IP address he will want to.
IMO it shouldn't be like that.
Changing current default behaviour of policy sounds for me like an RFE which should be discussed by drivers team.

The original intention is to allow user to add additional ip address to the port when the port is already associated with other ips. I'm not sure why we chose to not allow user to create port with specific ip, maybe we can allow that as well to make it consistent? We can address that in a different patch.
so if You proposed constant for "rule:shared", maybe You can reuse it in other places? But that can be also done in follow up patch if You want

but this will allow also to change IP address to any other IP which user wants. So imagine the case:

1. User wants to create port in shared network (he isn't owner of this network) and choose some specific IP address, this is forbidden by policy now, user can only choose subnet from which IP will be chosen,
2. So user creates port with any IP address choosen by neutron,
3. User sends request to update port like:

    neutron port-update <port_id> --fixed_ip subnet=<subnet_id>,ip_address=<IP.WHICH.USER.WANTS>

and his port has got only this new IP address from now.
I don't think this is good behaviour.

I'm not sure your main concern here, we have following restriction now?
New IP is not in the subnet CIDR, not allowed.
IP is used by another port, not allowed.
So, it's ok for user to input any IP address, neutron will reject the invalid request.


And if user wants to remain the old IP of the port, just run like this:
openstack port set
--fixed-ip subnet=<subnet>,ip_address=<original_IP_address> --fixed-ip subnet=<subnet>,ip_address=<new_IP_address> <port>

My main concern is about changing default behaviour just like that :)
And currently default behaviour is that regular user can't choose IP address freely from shared network. He can choose subnet but not specify IP address.
I know that neutron will not allow to pick already used IP but that's not the problem here.

IMO if we want to change default policy, we should have RFE, discuss it and than change it in separate commit with release note and things like that.

neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py.message: It seems like this could generate a large number of RPC messages which would become a scale issue as you're pulling all DVR ports for the subnet. Something to keep in mind...

I don't know the complete neutron sources, but I started at the ip helper lib and climbed my way up to find out what was calling the code, which was responsobile for setting the arp entries and ultimately landed here, where my observations startet to make sense, why only one of two routers was updated.

As Swami mentioned in his review, the ARP entries should be cleaned be getting cleaned up. I think he's right to say we should look at that.

I'm just generally hesitant to introduce more RPC chatter. If RPC is the only solution to a problem then so be it, but I'd look at what Swami is suggesting. It seems like there is something else going on.
Scale here is actually driven by the number of computes where the routers are instantiated. That actually comes out to (num routers) * (num local DVR routers).

The number of RPC messages depends on the number of dvr routers you have in your subnet. So for most people the impact is next to nothing. If you have 100 routers in your subnet, then ofc, this generates 100 RPC messages.

Ok, but still, this changes nothing for most users. Unless you have more than one DVR router in your subnet. Previously the generator only returned one router id, which led to stale permanent ARP entries. Do you have any suggestion for a better fix, other then notify all routers?

doc/source/stable-branches.rst.message: Also mention that some project like nova actually enforce this via a Zuul job?
Also mention the release-related patches (changing branch refs etc.)?

Adding prefixes to the commit title is not any sort of standard mechanism for incorporating metadata (though it's often seen in changes not intended for approval like [WIP] or [DNM]), so we're effectively making up an arbitrary new means of incorporating metadata as well as stealing an additional 14 characters from an already constrained space as many projects want to limit commit titles to 50 characters. This reduces the available length of those commit titles by 28% to 36 available characters, which may result in less meaningful titles in our autogenerated patches in particular. Commit message footers are a standard for us already, used for things such as change dependencies, bug/task mapping, signalling to interested parties, and even relied on by Gerrit for identifying the change to which a revision belongs.

Julia makes a good point, my understanding of the situation is that it's less about reviewers in this context, and more that the Nova team processes a large number of backports and wants an automated means of rejecting any which lack the cherry-pick attribution they insist be included in commit messages. As a small subset of changes to stable branches are not (and can't be) cherry-picked from newer branches, they're looking to standardize a mechanism by which the authors or generators of those packages can bypass that automated check.

Not wanting to bikeshed this, if Nova's commit message checks are already fine with "Stable-Only: <reason>" then I think that's the best mix of clarity and backward-compatibility with what you have. It also allows us to conveniently explain the reason it's stable-only with some standard terms which help to avoid excess boilerplate prose in the rest of the commit message, e.g. "Stable-Only: autogenerated" or "Stable-Only: updates branch-specific metadata" or whatever.
This unnecessarily lengthens the commit title, can we standardize on a commit footer line for this instead, like we already do for pretty much everything else?

IMO, it gives clear visibility of knowing that this backport is only for stable and having that in commit-msg make easy, and then reviewer start reading the context of why is if stable-only. I think it's a very small number of cases where it will extend the commit title, and it is easy to miss to read it from commit message body, especially where commit-msg body is too lengthy.

doc/source/stable-branches.rst.message:
The counter argument is commit messages should already explain everything as to what and why.

I kind of wonder what exactly is the goal here? Identify for reviewers? Identify for accounting purposes? 

Granted, information and context is good, but if the attempt is to guide the community wide culture, some clarity behind the driver is useful for some.

Yepp, that is possible, what do you suggest regarding the format?

- "Patch is stable-only." 
- "stable-only"
- "Stable-Only: <explanation>"
- ?

Note: Nova's validator does not require to have this on the title, it accepts it anywhere in the commit message (but we usually put it to title), case-insensitive manner.

Firstly, let me emphasize that I don't have strong feelings about where to place 'stable-only' in the commit message, though we *usually* place it to the title, that is what we got used to. Maybe a bit better (to me) to add it like a prefix of the title as it can be recognized right away. I don't even think that the length of the commit message title would be such a big problem (saying this so that I usually try to fit into the 50 chars), I sometimes see very long commit message titles (and some really short ones, like 'Fix zuul job' or similar that is worse, imho) so I think this is the less problematic part.

For another option: I could list here both case (prefix in title, 'Stable-Only: <explanation>' in body) as acceptable possibilities.

Anyway, if we have a consensus where to put it, I can adapt.

As a stable core who reviews many stable patches I feel it useful to see at a first glance that something is not a backport. I'm not saying it couldn't be done without this attention-grabbing method (reviewers has to read the commit message anyway), but still it puts the patch in context right away in my opinion.

In addition, since this 'tag' was more or less used already in Nova, we started to use it to let our validator bypass the check that a cherry pick is carried out properly, too.

So yes, it has two purposes nowadays in Nova: it is useful for reviewers + makes our tooling work. Both cases importance are equal in my opinion.
+1, it would be good to replicate fungi's examples as well.

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message: We will want/need to support the extension in this case as well.

I don't think this is what we want. If I understand the query correctly, it gets all the entries in the new no-NAT CIDRs table, and joins those with the network extension table entries with matching IDs, and finally filters out only those networks in the specified ACI VRF. This means that it will add CIDRs for private networks in that VRF, even if the private network isn't connected to a neutron router. I think we need to include some check about whether the network is connected to a router.

I'm concerned about removing this return. The comment above says that VRFs with one or two address scopes can't be associated with unscoped subnets. Without the return, the unscoped subnets would be added to any scoped ones from the queries above. Can't the return be left in?

I'm not sure this will work. In the case where there are multiple networks in the same VRF, each of which are connected to neutron routers, which are connected to the same external network, this would only verify the path of just one of the routers.

We could instead try starting with the subnets returned in line 901, find the networks that they are connected to, and see which of those networks are connected to routers which are in turn connected to external networks.

Instead of making an additional query, I'm wondering if you could tweak the queries that return the subnet CIDRs to also return the network IDs? If so, you can just us python list comprehensions to create lists of subnet CIDRs and lists of network IDs, which would save an additional round trip to the DB.

Can this be combined into a single query with a join and filter? We want to minimize the round trips to the DB, so cutting down on the number of distinct query API calls in sqlalchemy where possible (particularly for this path, since it's used in the get_gbp_details RPC, which is done for each port) is important.

I'm wondering if we can reduce the number of queries here. Instead of doing a for loop of queries per network, I'm wondering if we can do a single query to join subnets and ports whose device_owner is a router interface, returning a list of router IDs. Those IDs can then be used for an additional query joining ports with networks and the external network extension. Any set of those can be used to return the list of additional CIDRs from the external networks. The intent is that it turns a for loop into two queries (with some surrounding python code to make any needed data structures).

I agree with Ghanshyam, we need to be careful with the example code because people will tend to copy it.  The API call governed by the policy in this example was specifically designed to be used only by services, so there would be no reason for an admin to make the call.

There may be cases where it would make sense to have admin-or-service as the default (for example, when only a service can create some entity, but an admin may need to be able to delete it in case the operation was interrupted and the entity is left hanging around), but let's let the projects figure those out themselves.  I think the example should be service-only to prevent unthinking extension of these service-only API calls.

specs/keystone/yoga/default-service-role.message: Will there be a DB migration to apply this during upgrades?

``keystone-manage bootstrap`` is idempotent, so the guidance for an upgrade would be to run the command again.  The ``keystone-manage`` bootstrap will only add a ``service`` role if it does not already exist.  Given that this does not affect the DB schema, I don't think a DB migration is necessary.
Any update on this?
While that may work, it's not in the documented keystone upgrade procedure: https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/upgrading.html

One thing to mention explicitly, for 'service' token/role-policy, we will still enforce the same scope of APIs. So, for example, in API mentioned in L68, a service role with project scoped will be allowed. And in the case of system-level APIs (not sure if services are accessing the system-level APIs of other services, but in case there is any), a service role with system scope is allowed.

There has been some discussion on the ML on this topic.

In Kolla we are planning to assign the service role to users in the Yoga release, to avoid temporarily giving them system-reader to conform to the new policy defaults (currently they all have admin in the service project). What I'd like to know is, should we assign the service role with project scope or system scope? System makes more sense to me for most of the APIs that services use, however I'd like to go with a common approach.

It would also be helpful to know whether keystone is on track to meet the yoga timeline outlined in the SRBAC spec (in particular changing the default policies).

it cannot be system scoped as it is for project level resource. to generate the server external event, you need to know the server-uuid which system user does not have any knowledge of.

That is why my earlier point was, we will keep scope as per the APIs for user access control and openstack services will access then with special role called 'service' with scope to same as what calling API has.

I understand that point. And if we can make such API to be used only for OpenStack services then I agree but we cannot do that. These APIs can/are used and seen by users also (admin etc). Even we mention/tell that these are internal APIs and are not meant to be used by other than OpenStack services, there might be someone using them, so for that use case, we need to have proper scope.

I hope we could have a better way to design these internal APIs then your point makes sense. IF we could in some way, I love to make them internal APIs that cannot be used outside of openstack. It helps us in maintenance also.

I feel like we are going around in circles here. Yes, it is a project level resource, but in this case the project that owns the resource is not the one that is in scope - it is another 'dummy' project used just to meet this requirement. In any normal API, trying to access the resource of another project would lead to a 403 forbidden error.

Anyway, I've made my point a few times over now. I'm not involved in the implementation of this stuff, so perhaps there are things I'm missing.
This sounds like a circular argument to me. If we have to create some dummy project just to use an API, maybe the API should not be project-scoped?

> this particular policy 'os_compute_api:os-server-external-events:create'  will che changed to project scope (project admin), I am in progress of changing those. 

Which project will be in scope for that API? The project of the resource in the event, or the service project?

Is the caller of that API typically a real user or a service user?

Although these APIs are still in flux, and some (e.g. token validation) allow multiple scopes.

For any communication that is asynchronous from a user request (e.g. neutron -> nova callbacks), the credentials would need to be generic, and consumed from config. If the credentials were project-scoped, this would not be the project of the associated resource, rather something like the service project. At which point this API looks to me like it should be system-scoped.

In short, the service project to me mostly seems like an artifact of keystone v2, when everything was project scoped. With v3, surely it is time to free ourselves of this mostly unnecessary project?

The only case where I can see a use for a service project is where a service creates or owns actual resources that must be associated with a project.
Users can still use system-scoped APIs.
to pass the project scoped policy like external event, user with service role needs to be in some project right? though we do not use that project id for autherization.

this particular policy 'os_compute_api:os-server-external-events:create'  will che changed to project scope (project admin), I am in progress of changing those. 

But yes, even for async call, service role can be scoped to the one used in that particular API policy. Having by default scope is good idea but I will say we can have it as project scoped as that will be most of the service-to-service communication.

>Although these APIs are still in flux, and some (e.g. token validation) allow multiple scopes.

Yes, in this case like token validation using any scope is fine as they all are allowed.


>For any communication that is asynchronous from a user request (e.g. neutron -> nova callbacks), 

Any example of such callback which is not via APIs? I think every service-to-service communication is via APIs and each API is scoped to either project, system, or domain. That is why I think using the same allowed scopes what APIs allow is right way for 'service' role also.

I do not think should allow 'service' role without scope checks that can open a security issue for users accessing with 'service' role. Even for service-to-ervice communication, scope has to be same/enforced as what APIs is and users does.

for scope for service role, yes it will be same as what scope if there for default policy. IMO (as I mentioned in ML[1]), any project will use the service role to communicate to other service with the scope default to that particular API. For example, neutron will call nova's server external APIs (which is scoped to project) with service role and project scoped token.

I am not sure if any system level APIs are called between services if so then system scope will be used with service role.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2022-January/026789.html

> Yes, in this case like token validation using any scope is fine as they all are allowed.

Yes, understood. As a deployment tool, Kolla Ansible needs to choose which scope to assign the service role to service users, and I'm trying to work out what is the best choice.
 
> 
> Any example of such callback which is not via APIs? I think every service-to-service communication is via APIs and each API is scoped to either project, system, or domain. That is why I think using the same allowed scopes what APIs allow is right way for 'service' role also.
> 
> I do not think should allow 'service' role without scope checks that can open a security issue for users accessing with 'service' role. Even for service-to-ervice communication, scope has to be same/enforced as what APIs is and users does.

I'm not suggesting we remove any scope checks. When I said callback I was referring to API calls, but those which are not generated synchronously with a user request, and so don't have the user's context.

An example is the nova external events API, which neutron calls asynchronously, currently using an 'admin' context.

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=run-events-detail#create-external-events-os-server-external-events

Here's the policy:

os_compute_api:os-server-external-events:create
Default
rule:system_admin_api

Operations
POST /os-server-external-events

Scope Types
system

Create one or more external events

So it needs a system-scoped admin role, which doesn't really help us here.

Overall, I'm still inclined towards a setup where service users have a system-scoped service role by default and get project-scoped roles where necessary.

I don't know whether service to service integration uses mainly project or system scoped APIs.  I think that many will be project-level APIs given that system scope is relatively new.  My suggestion would be to grant the "service" role on the "service" project as shown below (lines 79-83)

I agree that project scope makes sense in many cases, but for this particular API I'm not so sure.

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/commit/f324ddf769b9d9b68530a191dcf2e419ff2c25d4/neutron/notifiers/nova.py#L88

The nova client created by neutron for this purpose does not use a user context, it uses auth config in the [nova] section. Currently this is a user with the admin role. The user will not realistically have a role in the project of the resource that it is generating an event about, so I don't see how a project-scoped API could work.
It sounds like it could work, I just don't understand why we need a service project.

In this (server external event APIs) case, as per new guidelines, neutron's get port is project scoped and from there neutron gets the server-uuid (device-id from port) to send the external event to nova. So we can modify the  'os_compute_api:os-server-external-events:create' to project scoped.

With service role, below can be the flow:

-  'os_compute_api:os-server-external-events:create' scoped to project and default to check_str='role:admin or role:service' (as proposed in this spec @L68)
- neutron is configured in nova section with users belong to service project and role assigned as 'service' (we do not need admin role assignment for service user).
- neutron call nova API with that project scoped and 'service' role with service project id. neutron does not need to send the project-id of servers it is generating the event for.
- Nova policy will pass as calling user is 'service' role. Nova will not check any project-id in this call.

Does it sound good?

Yes, Mark, your are right. if these profiles have to be removed, actually there are two problems:

The build phase or deploy phase(maybe in kickstart)? If this will done in build phase, according with Bob's comments above, he think that we should patch the source packages, but according with my investigation, at least there are 7 packages（apparmor, ntp, sssd-common, man-db, tcpdump, strongswan, keystone）need to be patched for this, I'm not inclined to do that also.  If this will be done in deploy phase, since I am not familiar with the upper layer configuration of starlingX, does anyone can tell me where is the right place to manipulate this?  

2. How to manipulate this?
Put the profiles into '/etc/apparmor.d/disable' is better than roughly 'rm /etc/apparmod.d/', but 'apparmor' has some special auto loading behaviour, for example, I put all default profiles into the '/etc/apparmor.d/disable' and reboot:
sysadmin@controller-0:~$ aa-status
apparmor module is loaded.
1 profiles are loaded.
1 profiles are in enforce mode.
   docker-default
0 profiles are in complain mode.
0 processes have profiles defined.
0 processes are in enforce mode.
0 processes are in complain mode.
0 processes are unconfined but have a profile defined.

you can see that there is still 'docker-default' profiles loaded and enabled, but you never found the file 'docker-default' in whole rootfs,  the reason is here:
"Docker automatically generates and loads a default profile for containers named docker-default. The Docker binary generates this profile in tmpfs and then loads it into the kernel." [refer to: https://docs.docker.com/engine/security/apparmor/], this is just one case, even I put all that default profiles I know to '/etc/apparmor.d/disable', I am afraid I still cat not say 'ok, all default profiles are disabled'.
Yes, this should be abandoned. thanks.
Thanks for the reply Greg. I think this is a sane approach.

Hey Chuck,

Our initial introduction of AppArmor is to enable the ability to run hosted application containers under AppArmor profiles.  ( It is future work to run Linux and StarlingX Daemons under AppArmor profiles. )

Enabling AppArmor has a performance degradation.
We want the performance degradation to be as small as possible by having as few profiles loaded and attached as possible.
So would like that, by default, there are NO AppArmor profiles loaded at all, when enabling AppArmor.

Greg, Like Chuck I have concerns as this will definitely reduce the security posture of STX which for the project should be a concern. Does the STX project have specific performance metrics which this is negatively impacting?

My ideal approach would be to evaluate each profile and keep as many as possible, disabling those that are problematic until we can assess why they are negatively impacting performance. At any rate, as I am not a member of the TSC I can only make recommendations.

As to the apprach taken, Haiqing, we should not be manipulating files installed by packages in this way. AppArmor provides mechanisms to disable profiles. Did we look into using '/etc/apparmor.d/disable'?
Greg, can we maybe use the docker profile as a beachhead to review if it actually negatively impacts performance?

Hey Mark,

This does not reduce the security posture of STX, since we do NOT run any MAC today; i.e. no SELINUX in CentOS and no AppArmor in Debian.

Yes we do see performance impact.

Our performance impact testing is actually seeing some odd results.
We'd actually like to do exactly what you are saying and test with no profiles and then incrementally add profiles to see impact of individual profiles.
Our preferred method to do this would be if the system would reboot with no profiles present.

Perhaps initially we should clean up performance impact testing
- with apparmor disabled
vs
- with apparor enabled with default profiles
... so the results we are seeing makes sense.
And then revisit whether we want to remove these default profiles.
'aa-teardown' can be run to unload all AppArmor profiles for you to do your tests.
The requirement is no any default profiles are shipped.

debian-mirror-tools/config/debian/common.message:
A couple of comments:

- I'd prefer to see these types of changes that impact the installed system in the kickstarts so that all non-build related changes are in one place.
- If the default profiles provided by the apparmour aren't working as we intend, shouldn't we just disable apparmor until they are tuned properly? Without the profiles isn't this just the equivalent of turning it off?

Thinking about this some more... If you really want to remove these profiles permanently, then the apparmor packages that deliver the files should be patched to remove them. We shouldn't need any kickstart/base_bullseye.yaml changes.

I think the way that is going about this is *totally* wrong. If we disable the apparmor profile then this leaves us with no security mitigation when a user installs starlingX. Which is a no go for most users who want to put this production. Removing this directory also will break things like libvirt which loads apparmor its own libvirt profile. 

I think the right way to solve this is try to understand what the issue is, provide details of what we are seeing and start to work with the apparmor developers. Maybe the issue has already been seen with the apparmor developers.

My preference is to remove them from the packages if we don't intend ship these in any form. Installing them and then removing them feels like a hack to me. With a package change to only install the files that we want, we don't have to carry and manage changes for removal here or in the kickstarts.

Thanks, my first thinking of this task is same to you to patch the packages. but one of my concerns is that '/etc/apparmor.d' is public place holder not only for 'apparmor' but also for other related packages like 'apparmor-profiles', maybe just patch only 'apparmor' can not meet the requirement of not ship any profiles, in addition, I think adding more and more packages into the STX source build list is not a good way, it not only takes more building resource, but also greatly increases the maintenance costs. The third thing is since the feature 'apparmor' is shipped, I think removing default profiles is one of the action of 'application configuration', then where is the user interface for starlingX to load customized profiles, can we added this 'clean default' action into that 'user configuration interface'?  thanks again

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Overall looks good to me, just a few nits and improvements

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/const.message: Add a new comment between line 1270 and 1271 to indicate that the check for controller and storage is for disk size and not for free space

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/healt.message: So given Bin's comment maybe change this variable to "min_free_space_needed" for the sake of clarity
I think this is not needed, since it will only fall in this elif if doesn't match with the condition in line #423

Just to clarify:
storage nodes require total root disk space not less than 120GiB
standard controller (w/o worker subfunction), require total root disk space not less than 220GiB
and for the worker nodes and AIO controllers (w/ worker subfunction), require 23GiB free disk space on the root disk in addition to the disk space has been allocated.

I don't think you can use the same error string for both scenarios.
For a host with worker functionality, you need to check if 23.5 Gib of unallocated space is available on the disk.  But for a storage or controller host you are checking if the disk is large enough.  The message back to the user is different for these 2 scenarios.
Maybe change to " free" if check_free_space else " total", so it will be "free disk space" or "total disk space" on the output
Must place this inside the loop, or else if set True for any host it won't initialize again with False for other hosts
It is not expected for a host to not fall under one of the conditions in lines 428, 430 and 432 so I think we're OK, but ideally this variable should also be initialized inside the loop

One more suggestion for the case where you detect not enough free disk space.  Suggest changing the error message reported to something that makes it more obvious this is due to not having enough disk space that is not allocated to any current disk partition.
Suggest you use something like this for that case:
Insufficient unallocated disk space on rootdisk. Current partitions have allocated disk space such that only <X>GiB is available but <Y>GiB unallocated disk space is needed
change diskspace to be 2 words: disk space

i wonder if this change would seem more sensible in a larger context of the ring v2 work and where you think the ring module's logging should go

I see a bug, I write a patch. I don't actually care much about logging in rings/builders -- though I *do* want some ability to get a warning out. This was just some weirdness I noticed because you pointed me at some code :P

swift/common/ring/builder.py.message: but.... this is like the ring builder's logger?  It apparently expects to have full control over the logger's enabled-ness.  I feel like we're trying to change the interface for some unspecified purpose - that will have almost no impact in practice.

Principle of least surprise -- the context manager should do its best to put things back the way they were. If you do what the CLI does and go to the trouble of saying

 logger = logging.getLogger("swift.ring.builder")
 logger.disabled = False
 logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
 logger.addHandler(handler)

before eventually doing something like

 with rb.debug():
     rb.rebalance()

I can't avoid this feeling that it'll be surprising to discover that logger.disabled is now True.

Side note: "disabled" isn't even a documented part of the Logger API! It doesn't appear *anywhere* on https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html

I feel like we'd be better off just doing something like

 if self.logger.level == logging.NOTSET:
     self.logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)

here and letting the CLI adjust the level down.

swift/obj/diskfile.py.message:
this is an EC specific implementation so should be in the ECDiskFile subclass.

If it is only ever called when handling an ECDiskFile that that might be sufficient, but you could make it 'generic' by naming it validate_metadata() and then having a default implementation here that is overridden with this implementation in ECDiskFile i.e.:

In BaseDiskFile...

  def validate_metadata(self):
      return True


In ECDiskFile:

  def validate_metadata(self):
      if self._datafile_metadata['X-Object-Sysmeta-Ec-Frag-Index'] or \
                self._datafile_metadata['X-Object-Sysmeta-Ec-Etag'] is None:
          return False
      else:
          return True

swift/obj/reconstructor.py.message:
so, the case we're addressing with this patch is a response that does have a frag index but does not have an etag?

If (and I realise it is not what we are expecting) the null-etag responses each had different frag indexes such that a 'useful bucket' worth of responses was collected, what would happen? I couldn't work out when/if things would blow up, or whether an empty frag would be reconstructed from the presumably empty responses. We don't seem to send the etag with the ssync PUT, so it's not checked...but should we check it?
Good -- we've written this header ever since EC first landed: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blame/master/swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py#L1983
So now we'll have a successful bucket with an etag of None...
And presumably we never get a second response to trip this None-return path.
And this is the trouble with dumping it the UNKNOWN_RESPONSE_STATUS bucket -- that prevents it from being considered a quarantine candidate.

openstackclient/compute/v2/server.py.message:
Is this something you'd consider a regular occurrence? The '--boot-from-volume' option is a shortcut for the following:

  --block-device id=$image,boot_index=0,source_type=image,destination_type=volume,volume_size=$size

There are various other properties we can configure as part of a BDM including 'device_type', 'disk_bus' and 'tag' and we don't want to expose a '--boot-from-volume-foo' opt for each of these. If this is a common enough operation then we can do this but if not I'd expect people to create their block devices the longer way.

5.7.0

Assuming a version of '--block-device' with that fix isn't good enough (is it), we could also 3) undeprecate '--block-device-mapping' and simply indicate that it's less powerful than '--block-device'? Both of the above options seem to give options that are similarly icky to type but less powerful than '--block-device'.

It's also worth noting that '--volume' and '--snapshot' have the same issue, in that they provide a shortcut version of '--block-device' but without any knobs. That's perfectly okay though, IMO: if you want all the power, use the longer '--block-device' option.
